cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: When traveling down a long downgrade, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and downshifting occasionally.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, you should use the braking effect of your engine as the principal way of controlling your speed. Save your brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: If cargo on a flatbed trailer is 40 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: Sending text messages while driving:
questions.answerA: May be done if the messages are short.
questions.answerC: Is permitted if you are asking a question of your employer.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is prohibited.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about how the weight is distributed.
questions.answerD: Only place weight over the axles.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a trailer should be evenly balanced. Having too much or too little weight on an axle can interfere with proper control of the vehicle. Additionally, having too much weight on one axle can damage it.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to a brake system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal  harder to depress.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with air brakes, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily may let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. This may cause the system's air pressure to become too low and the brakes to stop working.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: Parts of an exhaust system should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire:
questions.answerB: Use a B or C extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B and C type fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires. Water should never be used to extinguish an electrical fire because doing so could result in an electrical shock.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: Do not use the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerB: Do not use the driver's side mirror.
questions.answerD: Look in each mirror for long stretches of time.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Check all mirrors frequently while driving.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule to follow when using turn signals?
questions.answerC: Do not use your turn signal if you think others know what you plan to do.
questions.answerD: Cancel your signal after the turn is completed.
questions.explanation: To be certain that others are aware of your intentions, always signal whenever you plan to turn or change lanes. You should signal well in advance of a turn; signal continuously throughout the turn; and make sure to cancel the signal when you are finished turning.

questions.question: A suspension system:
questions.answerB: Uses pressurized water to support the load.
questions.explanation: Suspension systems receive weight capacity ratings, given by the manufacturers.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.answerD: Putting your hand out the driver's side window and waving.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If a vehicle gets stuck on a railroad track, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the vehicle and try to restart the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Try to flag down another vehicle to give them a push.
questions.answerD: Wait in the vehicle for a law enforcement officer to arrive.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, immediately exit the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check signs or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information. Call the emergency contact or call 911.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: If a CMV driver operates a CMV with a detectable blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is lower than 0.04 percent, they will be:
questions.answerC: Required to drive at speeds below 55 mph.
questions.explanation: If you are found to be operating a CMV with any detectable amount of alcohol in your system, but you are still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be placed out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When going down a steep downhill, your primary source of braking should be:
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill.

questions.question: Which of the following is not another name for convex mirrors?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are also known as "fisheye", "spot", or "bug-eye" mirrors.

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an activity that causes a distraction?
questions.explanation: Anything that takes your attention away from driving can be a dangerous distraction. This includes eating, drinking, smoking, or adjusting the vehicle's audio and climate controls.

questions.question: Joggers who are wearing headsets:
questions.answerA: Are usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can clearly hear sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may not be able to clearly hear surrounding traffic and may not be aware that you are there.

questions.question: The height of a vehicle’s center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on the handling the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Plays a large role in a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern when loading the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Should only be a concern if there are lots of hills on the planned route.
questions.explanation: The height of a vehicle's center of gravity is very important to a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle. Always distribute the weight of cargo as low as possible.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: When carrying a wide load, you should:
questions.answerB: Obtain special permits and follow special rules, such as driving during certain hours.
questions.answerC: Honk at other drivers to get them to move from the lane closest to you.
questions.explanation: Over-sized loads require special permits, may be allowed on the roads only at certain times, and may require special warning signs or equipment.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: The best way to avoid glare at night from oncoming vehicles is to:
questions.answerB: Close your eyes as vehicles approach.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of road.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded by the lights of oncoming vehicles, you can glance to the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: A truck may need to be under the legal maximum weight limit when being driven:
questions.explanation: Under some driving conditions, it may not be safe to operate a vehicle at its full legal maximum weight. Keep this in mind when driving in poor weather or on mountainous roadways.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks require special care because:
questions.answerA: They have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: They have high centers of gravity.
questions.explanation: Driving with a dry bulk tank requires special care, both because dry bulk tanks have high centers of gravity and because their loads often shift in transit. Be especially careful when taking turns and curves while operating such a vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a fire?
questions.explanation: Possible causes of vehicle fires include spilled fuel or improper use of flares following an crash; under-inflated tires or dual tires that touch; short circuits in the electrical system; smoking around fuel; improper fueling or loose fuel connections; and carrying cargo that is flammable, improperly sealed or loaded, or poorly ventilated.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.answerD: Putting your hand out the driver's side window and waving.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Usually are not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care when being driven because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should also be careful because the materials being carried can easily shift in transit, causing a change in the vehicle's handling.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Your headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Your headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Your headlights should be used, but only in the rain.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's headlights should be clean during trips. This will ensure that the lights can provide as much light as possible, helping the vehicle to be seen.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks require special care because:
questions.answerA: They have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: They have high centers of gravity.
questions.explanation: Driving with a dry bulk tank requires special care, both because dry bulk tanks have high centers of gravity and because their loads often shift in transit. Be especially careful when taking turns and curves while operating such a vehicle.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: When driving through a work zone, you should:
questions.answerD: Steer with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should observe posted speed limits. Slow down if road or weather conditions are poor, and slow down even further if workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a rule for using turn signals?
questions.answerC: Cancel your signal once your turn or lane change is complete.
questions.answerD: Don’t signal unless another vehicle is close.
questions.explanation: Always signal before a turn or lane change. Begin signaling well in advance of the movement and keep the signal on continuously during the turn. If it is not self-canceling, make sure to turn your signal off after your turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, what is the best way to make your vehicle more visible?
questions.explanation: In conditions of poor visibility (such as at dawn, at dusk, in rain, or in snow), you should turn on your low beam headlights to make your vehicle easier to see. Do not use your high beams when driving near other vehicles.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to remove the vehicle from the tracks.
questions.answerD: Walk down the tracks to look for an oncoming train.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: Who may operate a vehicle that requires placards to be driven?
questions.answerB: A driver with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A driver with a minimum of 10 years of commercial driving experience
questions.answerD: Any person who thinks they can
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a HazMat endorsement to operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerD: Can only be done in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: May be used on a tractor.
questions.answerB: May be used on a trailer.
questions.answerC: Should be used in adverse weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should not be used on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Having tires of mismatched sizes on a vehicle is a problem that should be fixed if discovered during a vehicle inspection.

questions.question: Which of the following may result in an applicant being denied a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.answerA: They are considered a security threat by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).
questions.answerB: They are a lawful U.S. citizen.
questions.answerC: They work for a foreign company.
questions.answerD: They do not have perfect vision.
questions.explanation: You will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you renounce your U.S. citizenship; are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; are wanted for, indicted for, or convicted of certain felonies; are judged mentally defective or are committed to a mental institution; or are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to pose a security threat.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answerA: The total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a vehicle before cargo
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle and its load of cargo.

questions.question: Drivers may use ____ red reflective warning triangles when their vehicle is stopped on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle carries red reflective triangles, the driver should place three of them as warning devices when the vehicle is parked on the road.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Slowly build up pressure over a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to a normal level within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease quickly while the engine runs.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be help a driver see a large area.
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are curved to provide drivers with wider views of the road than can be provided by flat mirrors. However, convex mirrors also make objects appear to be smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: When testing a parking brake, the vehicle should:
questions.answerB: Be placed in a low gear while the driver attempts to pull forward.
questions.answerC: Be inspected by a professional mechanic.
questions.answerD: Be driven while the parking brake is applied.
questions.explanation: To test a parking brake, you should fasten your safety belt, set the parking brake for the power unit, release the trailer parking brake (if applicable), place the vehicle in low gear, and attempt to pull forward against the parking brake. If the parking brake does not hold while you are attempting to pull forward against it, the brake is faulty and must be fixed.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on the front axle of a school bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the rear axles of a school bus.
questions.answerC: Cannot be used on a school bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not allowed to be used on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When parked on the side of a road, you should:
questions.answerD: Stand in the roadway and wave your arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers to alert other road users. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected only if they seem frayed.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be checked for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, your vehicle's braking distance will become ____ times longer.
questions.explanation: If you double your speed, your braking distance will become four times longer. Similarly, the impact your vehicle would have in the case of a collision will also multiply by four.

questions.question: What can change the height of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerD: Wave your arms at other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes after a tire failure could cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Unless you're about to hit something, stay off of the brake until the vehicle has slowed sufficiently.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You will likely be able to outdrive a train.
questions.answerB: You should not rely only on warning signals.
questions.answerC: You should roll a window down to listen for an approaching train.
questions.answerD: You should only worry about the track closest to your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should never rely only on warning signals to alert you to an approaching train. Never try to race a train to a crossing. If there are multiple tracks at a crossing, be sure to check all tracks in both directions before starting to cross.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerA: Exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerB: Exhaust system parts that are leaking
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts made of aluminum
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the road:
questions.answerB: Should be avoided by driving off the roadway.
questions.explanation: Any foreign object on the road is potentially dangerous. For example, something seemingly harmless, such as a cardboard box or paper sack, could contain a hard or heavy object that could do serious damage to a vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If required to complete a vehicle inspection report in writing, the report must be signed:
questions.answerB: Only if defects have been noted and certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: Only if the repairs are estimated to cost more than $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: You must sign the previous vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and certified to have been repaired or not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: If you don't know if there is enough space for your vehicle to pass under a bridge, you should:
questions.explanation: If you can't tell if your vehicle will have room to fit under a bridge or other overhead object, you should slow down and find an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: When looking under your vehicle's hood during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the parking brakes and/or chock blocks.
questions.answerB: Leave the vehicle in a low gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting under a vehicle's hood, make sure the parking brake is engaged and/or the wheels are properly chocked.

questions.question: If being shipped on either a flatbed trailer or a trailer without sides, cargo must be:
questions.answerC: Loose to allow it to shift when the vehicle turns.
questions.answerD: Heavy enough that it won’t shift.
questions.explanation: If being shipped on a flatbed trailer or on a trailer without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle moves.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: While it is best to entirely avoid driving in fog, you should turn on your low beam headlights if you must drive in foggy conditions. Using high beams is a bad idea because the lights will reflect off of the fog and back into your eyes, making the road and its surroundings even more difficult to see.

questions.question: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure in your brakes, you should downshift, pump the brakes, and use the parking brake. Seek an escape route, such as an escape ramp, open field, or side street.

questions.question: When covering cargo, a cover that flaps in transit:
questions.answerB: Allows air to get to the cargo to keep it cool.
questions.explanation: If cargo is covered, the cover should not flap in the wind in transit. The cover could tear loose, uncovering the cargo while potentially blocking your view or the view of others.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Used when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: In general, a tank endorsement is required to a drive tank vehicle used to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is pushed down, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if it is warm outside.
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: If required to complete a vehicle inspection report in writing, the report must be signed:
questions.answerB: Only if defects have been noted and certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: Only if the repairs are estimated to cost more than $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: You must sign the previous vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and certified to have been repaired or not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: You may be tailgated when you can't drive fast enough to keep up with other traffic. If a heavy load is slowing you down, stay in the right lane, if possible.

questions.question: How much water is needed on a road surface for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: To best reduce the distractions of a cell phone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay on a single call for an entire trip.
questions.answerB: Turn the phone off before driving.
questions.answerC: Only us the phone to accept incoming calls.
questions.answerD: Use the phone to text rather than talk.
questions.explanation: If possible, you should avoid all cell phone distractions by turning it off before starting a trip and leaving it off until you reach your destination.

questions.question: Before beginning downhill, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerD: Rely only on braking to reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill. Relying too heavily on the brakes may cause them to overheat and fade, becoming less effective.

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your cell phone for texting instead of calling.
questions.answerD: Turn up the ringer on your cell phone.
questions.explanation: Areas with heavy traffic, road construction, large numbers of pedestrians, or severe weather demand extra attention from a driver. The driver should avoid all possible distractions while in such areas, including cell phone use.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: What is a danger of rolling back when you start to accelerate?
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.answerD: You may lose your position in traffic.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting someone or something behind you, it is important to ensure that your vehicle does not roll backwards when starting from a stop. If your vehicle has a manual transmission, partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: When inspecting cargo, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the truck is not overloaded.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the cargo is balanced.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the cargo is secured properly.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the breakable items are placed under heavier items.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected by a driver to ensure that it is properly secured, balanced, and not exceeding weight limits.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: If feeling tired and frequently yawning, you should:
questions.answerD: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: Frequent yawning is a warning sign of fatigue. If you become tired while driving, the only safe response is to stop and get some sleep. You cannot rely on artificial stimulants, like caffeine, to keep you alert because they will eventually wear off and leave you more tired than you originally were.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: Regarding winter driving, all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: Front tires should have a tread depth of at least 4/32 an inch.
questions.answerC: Rear tires should have a tread depth of at least 2/32 an inch.
questions.answerD: Use a gauge to verify that each tire has a safe tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is particularly important that your tires have adequate tread. You need a tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch on the back tires. Check the tread depths by using a gauge.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating?
questions.answerA: The maximum weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a single vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a single vehicle
questions.answerD: The maximum amount that can be loaded onto a single trailer
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the weight specified by the manufacturer as the maximum weight of a single vehicle and its load.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Have air pressure in the braking system even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking system when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build air pressure to allow the brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Maintain air pressure when shut off for periods of less than four hours.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential effect of drinking alcohol then driving?
questions.explanation: Driving errors that may be caused by alcohol-induced impairment include straddling lanes; quick, jerky starts; failure to signal or use lights; running stop signs and red lights; and improper passing. A driver's reaction time will become poor when they are under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerB: The vehicle touching an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerC: A driver properly completing an exercise in the skills test.
questions.answerD: An applicant trying to bribe the examiner.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: Which of the following can help you determine when to upshift?
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: On a leaf spring, the leaves:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: Texting while driving a CMV is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if the text is work-related.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if there are fewer than 10 words in the text message.
questions.answerC: Encouraged because it is safer than talking on the phone.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a commercial motor vehicle is both illegal and dangerous. Manually entering text into or reading text from any electronic device is considered texting.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of road workers, drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, and children near the road.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the vehicle to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble while you are driving, you should stop and inspect the source of the unusual occurrence.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase the distance between you and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Avoid relying on tricks to help others pass.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely, you should increase your following distance, avoid making quick moves, and avoid relying on tricks (such as flashing your lights) to help other drivers pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing the tailgater to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.answerD: A minute of hitting the brakes.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerC: May contain a heavy object that could damage your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided by driving off the roadway.
questions.explanation: Any foreign object on the road is potentially dangerous. For example, something seemingly harmless, such as a cardboard box or paper sack, could contain a hard or heavy object that could do serious damage to a vehicle.

questions.question: If you are not sure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure that you have enough room to safely fit underneath a bridge or other overhead object, you should slow down and seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer ____ of the violation.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks require special care because:
questions.answerA: They have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: They have high centers of gravity.
questions.explanation: Driving with a dry bulk tank requires special care, both because dry bulk tanks have high centers of gravity and because their loads often shift in transit. Be especially careful when taking turns and curves while operating such a vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching an active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear any approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train as it approaches.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of the train's horn.
questions.answerD: There will always be flashing warning lights.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing, do not assume that you will hear an approaching train. Trains may be prohibited from sounding their horns in certain areas, or the sound of its horn may be covered by noise from your vehicle. Do not assume that warning lights or other signals will announce a train.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: First turn the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: First turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing a straight truck, you would turn the wheel in the direction you want to go. By contrast, when backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Do not use the parking brake when parking if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.answerD: There is water on the ground.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: To obtain a passenger endorsement, applicants must be at least:
questions.explanation: You must be at least 18 years old to obtain a CDL. However, you must be 21 years old to drive in interstate commerce or to obtain a passenger or hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: Too little weight on a steering axle can result in:
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle needs to be balanced appropriately so that it does not interfere with the vehicle's safe handling. For example, if cargo is placed too far to the rear of a vehicle, the front axle will be under-weighted and the front wheels may not have enough traction for the driver to steer safely.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a fire?
questions.explanation: Possible causes of vehicle fires include spilled fuel or improper use of flares following an crash; under-inflated tires or dual tires that touch; short circuits in the electrical system; smoking around fuel; improper fueling or loose fuel connections; and carrying cargo that is flammable, improperly sealed or loaded, or poorly ventilated.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Rims with a missing lug nut are acceptable if there are at least four other lug nuts on the rim.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring is acceptable if the vehicle is being driven at speeds under 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.answerD: Welded repairs are acceptable for wheels on rear axles.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs can be a dangerous defect. Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are not safe to be used. Wheels or rims with welded repairs are not safe.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: In a convex mirror, objects seem ____ than they actually are.
questions.explanation: A convex mirror makes objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal:
questions.explanation: When stopping, the brake pedal should be pushed down gradually. Control the pressure so your vehicle comes to a slow, safe stop.

questions.question: How could you reduce your stress while driving?
questions.explanation: Being under stress can lead to aggressive driving, which is dangerous. Playing calming music can help you become more relaxed if you are feeling stressed while driving.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop and take a break ____ to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of becoming fatigued on a long trip, a driver should stop for a break at least once every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: A bus mechanic must have:
questions.explanation: Bus mechanics are required to have passenger endorsements.

questions.question: How can you prevent drowsiness before a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about four hours of sleep.
questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerD: Drive faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the day.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When double clutching, if you remain in neutral for too long and can’t get your vehicle into the next gear, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop the vehicle and start over.
questions.answerB: Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase your speed, and try again.
questions.answerC: Skip over your intended gear and move into the next gear.
questions.answerD: Just keep the vehicle in neutral.
questions.explanation: If you stay in neutral for too long while double clutching and have difficulty switching your vehicle into the next gear, don't force it. Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Slowly build up pressure over a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to a normal level within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease quickly while the engine runs.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: In an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerD: Always turn on your flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest option when responding to an emergency while driving. It is usually safer to steer out of the way when attempting to avoid a crash.

questions.question: After driving over a bridge during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall.
questions.answerB: The color of a sign you just passed.
questions.answerC: How many lanes of traffic there were on the bridge.
questions.answerD: If there was a crosswalk on the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you drive over a bridge during the on-road driving skills test, the examiner may ask you afterwards to recall the bridge's posted weight limit.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail due to:
questions.answerC: Driving uphill for long periods of time.
questions.explanation: Failure of hydraulic brakes is often caused by a loss of hydraulic pressure. Hydraulic brakes may also fade because of overuse on a long downgrade.

questions.question: Suspension system defects may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Defects to check for when inspecting your vehicle's suspension system include cracked or broken spring hangers; missing or broken leaves in a leaf spring; and leaking shock absorbers. If you spot any of these issues, be sure to have them repaired.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a way to prevent drowsiness during a trip?
questions.answerA: Getting an adequate amount of sleep before driving
questions.answerC: Scheduling trips during hours when you would not normally be awake
questions.answerD: Avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you so you can take turns driving; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: Which part of the truck is the air compressor connected to?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: What do headers do?
