questions.answerA: Protect the driver during a crash
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards protect the driver from the forward motion of their cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: Once cargo is secured:
questions.answerA: You may complete an entire trip without checking it.
questions.answerB: You can drive at least eight hours without checking it.
questions.answerC: You should check it every three hours or 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Parts of an exhaust system should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you may be slowing down, you should:
questions.explanation: When you plan to slow down, it is often a good idea to lightly tap your brakes to make the brake lights flash. Doing this will help let drivers behind you know about your intentions.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: A suspension system:
questions.answerB: Uses pressurized water to support the load.
questions.explanation: Suspension systems receive weight capacity ratings, given by the manufacturers.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, release the accelerator and push in the clutch. This will slow down your vehicle and help it regain traction.

questions.question: What should be done shortly after a tire has been changed?
questions.answerA: The driver should stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight after driving for a bit.
questions.answerB: The driver should repair the brakes.
questions.answerC: The driver should deflate the tire to 10 psi.
questions.answerD: The driver should inflate the tire.
questions.explanation: After changing a tire, you should stop after driving for a while to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help a school bus driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Let students know when it is safe to board.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure that all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.answerD: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.explanation: Students should always board a school bus in a single-file line.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: When should a bus start moving after students have boarded?
questions.answerA: As soon as the students are through the door
questions.answerB: When the students are near their seats but are still standing
questions.answerC: When the students are seated and looking forward
questions.answerD: As soon as the students cross the standee line
questions.explanation: Once students have boarded a school bus, the driver should wait to move the bus until all of the passengers are seated and looking forward.

questions.question: After traveling under an overpass during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall:
questions.answerD: If there was a shoulder near the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you drive under an overpass during the on-road driving skills test, your examiner may ask you to recall the posted clearance or height of the overpass.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if students are given notice of the change.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students and parents.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the school and not changed.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should never change or add a stop without written approval from the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: The overhead inside mirror should be adjusted to see:
questions.answerA: Outside of the driver’s side of the bus.
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.answerC: Students in the first four rows of the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The pedal surface has been smoothed out.
questions.answerD: There is something underneath the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, you should park at least 10 feet away from the students:
questions.answerA: So they must walk to the bus, providing you with a better view of their movements.
questions.answerB: Because it is difficult to get any closer to the students.
questions.answerC: Because students should walk for exercise.
questions.answerD: Because a student may show up late.
questions.explanation: When picking up students at a bus stop, you should come to a complete stop with the front bumper of the bus at least 10 feet away from the students. This forces them to walk toward the bus, allowing you to keep an eye on their movements.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: When should you inspect the mirrors on a bus?
questions.answerD: Is not necessary to inspect the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of a bus should always be inspected before a trip. Adjust them as necessary before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When you are approaching a bus stop, the students on your bus should:
questions.answerB: Stand up and collect their belongings.
questions.answerC: Walk to the front of the bus and prepare to exit.
questions.explanation: Students on a school bus should remain seated until they are told otherwise. It is unsafe for students to walk around the bus while it is moving.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: The decision to proceed rests with each driver.
questions.answerB: The decision to proceed should be based on a control device.
questions.answerC: The decision to proceed should be based on surrounding vehicles.
questions.answerD: The decision to proceed is left to passengers in each vehicle.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: There are blind spots ____ left and right side flat mirrors.
questions.explanation: There are blind spots immediately below and in front of each outside flat mirror. These mirrors have another blind spot directly behind the rear bumper.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: If a shipping paper has both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Written the same way as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When a shipping paper includes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, one acceptable method of identifying the hazardous items is to highlight them in a contrasting color.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Who must provide emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide emergency response information to drivers.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: To distinguish between hazardous and non-hazardous materials on a shipping paper:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials should be listed at the bottom of the paper.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials should be listed at the top of the paper.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials should be highlighted in the same color as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.answerD: The non-hazardous materials should be marked with an "X."
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be differentiated in one of three ways. They must be listed first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description in a column labeled "HM."

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: How is a hazardous materials warning presented?
questions.answerB: By wrapping the package in orange
questions.answerC: By placing the item away from other cargo and covering it with a sign
questions.explanation: Signs are placed on the outside of vehicles and bulk packages to warn drivers and others about hazardous materials. These diamond-shaped signs are known as "placards."

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers must include:
questions.answerC: The intended use of the materials.
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware of the risks associated with materials they are transporting. Hazardous materials shipping papers must include an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.answerD: The shipping paper is not in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to compare a shipping paper to the applicable package markings and labels. Ensure that the shipper has included the correct basic description on the shipping paper and that it matches markings and labels.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Get someone else to drive it.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: Shipping papers identifying hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerA: At the bottom of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerB: On the top of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerC: In a location separate from non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Carriers and drivers must be able to quickly identify hazardous materials' shipping papers. Shipping papers for hazardous materials should be on the top of a stack of shipping papers.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Due to the risks involved, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials. These regulations exist to protect the driver, others near the vehicle, and the environment.

questions.question: When accepting a package of hazardous materials, a driver should ensure:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: That all packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: When carrying hazardous materials, it is a good idea to compare the shipping papers to the markings and labels on the packages.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By any driver, as long as the total weight of the hazardous materials are under 50 pounds.
questions.answerC: By any driver in a rural area.
questions.answerD: By a driver with a CDL and HazMat endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: At least how many placards must be placed on a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is required to have hazardous materials placards, at least four identical placards must be displayed. These placards must be placed on the front, back, and both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.explanation: The emergency response information for a cargo of hazardous materials must include details about risks of fire or explosion associated with the materials.

questions.question: How long do shippers need to keep a copy of shipping papers for hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials must retain a copy or electronic image of the associated shipping papers for at least two years from the date that the material is accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Get someone else to drive it.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: A driver needs a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to transport hazardous materials in:
questions.answerA: A vehicle requiring a Class A license.
questions.answerB: A vehicle requiring a Class B license.
questions.answerC: A vehicle requiring a Class C license.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 10 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a non-sealed container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting mass explosives:
questions.answerA: The vehicle must always be placarded.
questions.answerB: The vehicle only needs to be placarded if carrying more than 200 pounds.
questions.answerC: The vehicle does not need to be placarded.
questions.answerD: Only rural roads should be used.
questions.explanation: For some hazardous materials, placards are only required to be used if 1,001 pounds or more are being carried by a vehicle. For others, including mass explosives, placards are required to be used when carrying any amount of the material.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening the trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Put on a pair of gloves.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: If you notice hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.answerD: Drive around looking for a person to repair the leak.
questions.explanation: If a cargo leak develops while you are carrying hazardous materials, do not continue driving any farther than safety requires. The farther you drive, the larger the contaminated area will become. You should park the vehicle, secure the area, and stay with the vehicle while sending someone else to get help.

questions.question: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes:
questions.answerA: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper if a small piece of paper is being used.
questions.answerB: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper to make them easier to read.
questions.answerC: Should not be abbreviated on a shipping paper.
questions.answerD: Should only be abbreviated on a shipping paper if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes must never be abbreviated when listed on a shipping paper. The only exception to this is if the abbreviation is specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: How do you label a hazardous material if the proper label will not fit on the material's package?
questions.answerA: The label may be placed on a tag securely attached to the package.
questions.answerB: A scannable QR code may instead be attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The HazMat label should be reduced in size to fit on the package.
questions.answerD: The label may be pasted to the wall of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit on a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: When merging into traffic while driving a double or triple, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume there is enough space for the vehicle to merge.
questions.answerB: Be sure there is extra space for the vehicle to merge.
questions.answerD: Wait to merge until there is no traffic in the lane for at least two miles.
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations require more space than smaller vehicles to enter or cross traffic. This is not only because the vehicle itself is larger, but also because it needs a longer distance to accelerate.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: If required to complete a vehicle inspection report in writing, the report must be signed:
questions.answerB: Only if defects have been noted and certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: Only if the repairs are estimated to cost more than $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: You must sign the previous vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and certified to have been repaired or not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: About how many drinks does it take for a 200-pound person to reach a 0.02 percent blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairment begins long before the legal limit is reached. A 200-pound person will reach a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.02 percent after a single drink.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: What happens if the air pressure in a system's air tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light will come on.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will not shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low pressure warning signal should activate if the pressure in the air tanks falls to a level below 60 psi. This signal may be in the form of a warning light or a wig wag.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: When parked on the side of a road, you should:
questions.answerD: Stand in the roadway and wave your arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers to alert other road users. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: A converter dolly that has ABS can be identified:
questions.answerC: By a yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly.
questions.answerD: By a blue lamp on the left side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). A dolly with ABS must be identifiable by a yellow lamp on its left side.

questions.question: Improper coupling is:
questions.explanation: It is essential that drivers of doubles and triples are able to correctly couple and uncouple their trailers. Improperly coupling and uncoupling trailers is extremely dangerous.

questions.question: What causes the "crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification. Rearward amplification varies from vehicle to vehicle, so it is important that drivers are aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When approaching a downgrade, how can you reduce the amount of braking that will be needed?
questions.explanation: Always shift to a lower gear before starting down a hill. Doing this will help your vehicle maintain a safe speed without you needing to use the brakes too much.

questions.question: Improper coupling is:
questions.explanation: It is essential that drivers of doubles and triples are able to correctly couple and uncouple their trailers. Improperly coupling and uncoupling trailers is extremely dangerous.

questions.question: In poor weather, the driver of a double or triple should:
questions.answerA: Lead the way for other drivers.
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Drive carefully, as the vehicle is prone to skidding.
questions.explanation: In adverse weather conditions, special care must be taken when driving a double or triple. They are especially prone to skids, loss of traction, and rollovers.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable?
questions.answerA: Dual tires that do not come into contact with each other
questions.answerB: Tires of mismatched sizes if used only on short trips
questions.answerC: Retreaded tires on the front of a school bus
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should ensure that dual tires do not come into contact with each other or with other parts of the vehicle. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut or damaged in any way. Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on the posted signals to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerB: Rely on the movements of other motorists to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Not rely on signals to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerD: Look to see if nearby plants are moving from the breeze created by a passing train
questions.explanation: As a precaution, you should always approach a railroad crossing under the assumption that a train is coming. Do not rely only on signals or your hearing to indicate that a train is approaching.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Rims with a missing lug nut are acceptable if there are at least four other lug nuts on the rim.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring is acceptable if the vehicle is being driven at speeds under 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.answerD: Welded repairs are acceptable for wheels on rear axles.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs can be a dangerous defect. Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are not safe to be used. Wheels or rims with welded repairs are not safe.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: Always reduce your speed and downshift before entering a curve.

questions.question: When inspecting a tank, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Refer to their specific vehicle’s operator manual.
questions.answerC: Look online for information about the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Make sure there is no rust on the outside of the tank.
questions.explanation: Because there are many different types of tanks, each of which with its own specific features, a driver should always consult the operator's manual for information on how to inspect a particular tank.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerA: Exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerB: Exhaust system parts that are leaking
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts made of aluminum
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: Starting in which year were newly manufactured trailers required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good rule to follow when making a turn?
questions.answerB: Use your arms to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn off your turn signal before entering the turn to avoid confusing other drivers.
questions.explanation: Signal well in advance of a turn so drivers behind you are aware of your intentions. Keep the signal on throughout the turn and turn it off once the turn is complete.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, you should:
questions.answerA: Open your door for a better look.
questions.explanation: Mirror checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine. It is particularly important to make frequent mirror checks when driving in close quarters.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Regarding winter driving, all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: Front tires should have a tread depth of at least 4/32 an inch.
questions.answerC: Rear tires should have a tread depth of at least 2/32 an inch.
questions.answerD: Use a gauge to verify that each tire has a safe tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is particularly important that your tires have adequate tread. You need a tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch on the back tires. Check the tread depths by using a gauge.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: When driving in the winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is especially important to make sure the coolant and antifreeze are at safe levels.

questions.question: On a wet road, you should reduce your speed:
questions.explanation: You should reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: If you’re not sure how to handle a fire, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of which method is appropriate to use to extinguish a fire, you should wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially important when dealing with hazardous materials fires.

questions.question: If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push the tractor air supply control, you should:
questions.explanation: It is important that all of your vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before you begin a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: A sign indicating a maximum safe speed:
questions.answerA: Is suggesting a driving speed, but vehicles may travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.answerB: Is suggesting a speed limit to be followed only by vehicles weighing more than 26,000 pounds.
questions.answerC: Should be followed and no vehicle should travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.explanation: You should never exceed the speed shown on a "Maximum Safe Speed" sign.

questions.question: In an emergency, if you must leave the roadway to drive on the shoulder, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer so all wheels are on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stop safely before returning to the road, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on the shoulder until the next exit.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to drive onto the shoulder of a road, you should try to keep one set of wheels on the pavement to maintain better control of your vehicle. If possible, stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has come to a complete stop, then pull back onto the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Roads are most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Some tires are not designed for rain.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: A sign that your vehicle's brakes will need repair is that the:
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.answerC: The brake pads are worn thin.
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Air tanks usually hold enough compressed air:
questions.answerA: For one stop before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerB: For several stops before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerC: For a day’s worth of braking.
questions.answerD: For an unlimited number of stops.
questions.explanation: In an air braking system, the air storage tanks can usually hold enough compressed air for the brakes to be used several times.

questions.question: Which type of brakes do most heavy-duty vehicles have?
questions.explanation: For safety, most heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: A registered vehicle should have:
questions.answerA: A mirror on the left side only.
questions.answerB: Mirrors on both the left and right sides.
questions.answerC: A mirror on the right side only.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle. A vehicle should have mirrors on both sides, which should be checked regularly.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: While driving, your mirrors:
questions.answerB: Should only be used when changing lanes.
questions.explanation: While driving, regular mirror checks are essential to remaining aware of the traffic around you. Mirrors are also essential to helping you spot possible problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected only if they seem frayed.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be checked for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: If a leak is suspected in a cargo of radioactive material:
questions.answerA: The driver should go to the local fire department.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up any loose pieces of the radioactive material.
questions.answerC: The driver should continue to carry the cargo, as long as they avoid touching the affected areas.
questions.answerD: The driver should not operate the vehicle until it has been cleaned.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting radioactive material and believe there is a leak or broken package in your cargo, you should tell your dispatcher or supervisor as quickly as possible. Do not touch or inhale the material. Do not use the vehicle until it has been cleaned or checked with a survey meter.

questions.question: What is a way to warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down?
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate the brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get other drivers’ attention.
questions.answerD: Turn all lights on and off several times.
questions.explanation: To alert drivers behind you that you plan to slow down, tap your brake pedal lightly a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as a fire extinguisher, is:
questions.answerA: Only needed for vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
