questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: When entering fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn up the volume of the radio.
questions.explanation: If at all possible, it is best to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive through fog, slow down before reaching it.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge that is controlled by a traffic signal, you may proceed:
questions.answerB: Only after coming to a complete stop 50 feet before the bridge.
questions.answerC: Only if other vehicles are also proceeding.
questions.answerD: Only after getting out of your vehicle to check the conditions.
questions.explanation: If approaching a drawbridge that is controlled by a traffic signal displaying a green light, you may slow down and proceed without stopping.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) can be identified by:
questions.answerA: A sticker on the control panel.
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: The letters "ABS" on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: A metal plate on the inside of the driver’s side door.
questions.explanation: You can tell that your vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) if it has a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.

questions.question: Fatigue:
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous and increases the risk of a crash. Take precautions before a trip to prevent driving while fatigued.

questions.question: If driving in a foggy area, you should not:
questions.explanation: It is safest not to drive in foggy areas. However, if you must drive through fog, you should slow down, use your low beam headlights and fog lights, and turn on your four-way flashers.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it difficult to steer.

questions.question: When switching gears, what happens if you remain in neutral for too long?
questions.answerB: You may have trouble getting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.answerD: The vehicle will be difficult to stop.
questions.explanation: Remaining in neutral for too long when shifting gears may make it difficult to put the vehicle into the next gear.

questions.question: Before a bus enters a curve, the driver should:
questions.answerD: Move onto the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: Crashes on curves are usually a result of the operator driving too fast. A bus driver should always reduce their driving speed before entering a curve, turn, on-ramp, or off-ramp.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: What is a way to warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down?
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate the brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get other drivers’ attention.
questions.answerD: Turn all lights on and off several times.
questions.explanation: To alert drivers behind you that you plan to slow down, tap your brake pedal lightly a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a way to prevent drowsiness during a trip?
questions.answerA: Getting an adequate amount of sleep before driving
questions.answerC: Scheduling trips during hours when you would not normally be awake
questions.answerD: Avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you so you can take turns driving; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail for one of two reasons. Which of the following is one of those reasons?
questions.answerA: There is a loss of hydraulic pressure.
questions.answerD: The brakes are used too much in one day.
questions.explanation: Most hydraulic brake failures occur for one of two reasons. A first likely cause of brake failure is that the brakes have been overused on a downgrade, causing them to fade. The second likely cause is that there has been a loss of hydraulic pressure in the braking system. Brakes kept in good condition will rarely fail, but you should know which steps to take in case they do.

questions.question: Multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions are used:
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle run more smoothly.
questions.answerD: To make a vehicle less noisy.
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears. They are usually controlled by a selector knob on the gearshift lever.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.explanation: When passing a pedestrian or another vehicle, you should assume that they don't see you.

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: When passengers ride a bus:
questions.answerA: Leaving items in the aisle is acceptable.
questions.answerB: Leaving items in the aisle is acceptable while everyone is seated.
questions.answerC: There should be no obstacles in the aisle.
questions.answerD: An item may be left in the aisle if there is an orange cone beside it.
questions.explanation: Do not allow passengers to leave any items in an aisle while the bus is moving. Aisles and stairwells should always be free of obstructions.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.answerB: Any amount of solid Class 6 poisons.
questions.explanation: Buses may never be used to transport radioactive materials. Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poisons, tear gas, and irritating materials are also not permitted to be carried by bus.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to another person in a vehicle
questions.answerB: Children on the side of the road
questions.answerC: Construction workers on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Drivers who are holding conversations with others may not be paying full attention to the road and may make unsafe moves. Children do not always pay attention to traffic and may dart into the road without looking. Exercise caution when driving near road workers. This helps to keep the workers and other distracted drivers safe.

questions.question: Rules regarding passenger comfort, such as smoking guidelines, should:
questions.answerA: Not be mentioned unless there is a rule violation.
questions.answerB: Only be mentioned if a passenger specifically asks about something.
questions.answerC: Be announced at the start of the trip.
questions.answerD: Be discussed individually with each passenger.
questions.explanation: Many charter and intercity carriers have rules about passengers smoking, drinking, and using music players while on the bus. Explaining passenger rules at the start of a trip is often an effective way to avoid trouble later on.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that you could impede other vehicles, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with your emergency flashers activated.
questions.answerD: Wave an arm out of your window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should use your emergency flashers to warn other drivers. Be sure that the use of emergency flashers is permitted by local laws.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure every handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to use.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, you should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Rims with a missing lug nut are acceptable if there are at least four other lug nuts on the rim.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring is acceptable if the vehicle is being driven at speeds under 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.answerD: Welded repairs are acceptable for wheels on rear axles.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs can be a dangerous defect. Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are not safe to be used. Wheels or rims with welded repairs are not safe.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids under the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.answerD: To see if the vehicle is on a decline.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle to conduct an inspection, you should look underneath it to make sure there are no fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks on the ground. Leaks can indicate unsafe defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: If a driver begins to feel fatigued while driving, they should:
questions.answerD: Drive faster to finish the trip more quickly.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the only safe response is to safely leave the road and get some sleep. Using artificial stimulants can be dangerous because they may cause extreme fatigue when they begin to wear off.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: A curve's posted design speed is:
questions.answerB: Safe for all vehicles, including buses.
questions.answerC: The minimum speed at which the curve should be driven.
questions.explanation: Even under ideal weather conditions, a bus being driven at the posted design speed for a curve could either roll over or slide off the road. For safety, you should reduce your speed before driving a bus around a curve.

questions.question: In the event of an engine fire, you should not:
questions.answerA: Turn the engine off as soon as possible.
questions.answerD: Spray from the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you can avoid it. Shoot foam through the louvers or from the vehicle’s underside.

questions.question: If driving a charter bus, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Tell passengers how to operate the TVs, if equipped.
questions.answerB: Not allow passengers to board until the scheduled departure time.
questions.answerC: Allow passengers to board early to get ahead of schedule.
questions.answerD: Tell passengers to fill the back of the bus first.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until the scheduled departure time.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to a brake system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal  harder to depress.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with air brakes, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily may let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. This may cause the system's air pressure to become too low and the brakes to stop working.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle using air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal toward them.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in an air-braked vehicle, push the brake pedal down and control the pressure so that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Used when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: In general, a tank endorsement is required to a drive tank vehicle used to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Emergency brakes are:
questions.answerD: Only required when transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes.

questions.question: Which part of the truck is the air compressor connected to?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required to transport both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a tank endorsement is required to operate a tank vehicle that is used to haul either liquids or gases.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment:
questions.answerC: If they are used at all.
questions.answerD: If brakes on one side are used more often than brakes on the other side.
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out out adjustment if they are hot. Use proper braking techniques to avoid letting your brakes overheat.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.answerD: Clean the air in the passenger compartment.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes. Manually operated drains should be used daily.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: When uncoupling a trailer, landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: Glad hands are:
questions.explanation: On trailers with air brakes, glad hands are coupling devices used to connect the air lines of the tractor to those of the trailer.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line is also referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will often continue to move in a straight line.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: Operating a combination vehicle usually requires ­­­­­____ operating a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.answerD: Exactly the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more skill to drive than single vehicles. Combination vehicles are usually longer and heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollovers.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when drivers:
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver taking a turn at too high a speed. Be sure to take turns and curves safely and slowly.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for service lines?
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line is also referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand brake while experiencing a trailer jackknife will:
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.question: Emergency air lines are often coded with the color:
questions.explanation: In general, the parts of the service air line are coded blue and the parts of the emergency air line are coded red.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line may also be referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: What does the tractor protection valve do?
questions.answerA: Protects the tractor from being stolen
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a leak
questions.answerD: Ensures oil adequately lubricates the engine
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.

questions.question: If the trailer begins to skid, it is best to:
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel one way, then the other.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to help regain traction. Once the wheels grip the road again, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the path of the tractor.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for emergency lines?
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: What is a bobtail?
questions.answerC: A tractor that goes faster than the speed limit
questions.answerD: A tractor that goes slower than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.
